metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of Wudaoliang diorite in the Hoh Xil area, northern Tibet
metadata.description: The data set includes major and trace elements, major mineral elements, whole rock SR – Nd isotope, zircon u – Pb age and Hf isotope data of diorite. Samples were collected from diorite in Wudaoliang area of Hoh Xil block, northern Tibet. Zircon U-Pb dating data were obtained by laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. Hf isotopic data of zircons were obtained by laser ablation multiple acceptor inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The major and trace geochemical data of the whole rock are obtained by X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The data of major elements in minerals are obtained by electron microprobe analysis. The whole rock SR – Nd isotopes were obtained by sample separation and purification multi receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Through the data obtained, we can define the age, origin and deep dynamic mechanism of magmatism in the region, and provide knowledge on the origin of high magnesian characteristics of continental crust.
metadata.instructions: All data are stored in Excel file. The file name "zirupb. XLS" represents zircon U-Pb geochronology data. The file name "zirhf. XLS" represents zircon Hf isotope data. The name of the file "wrmajtraiso" represents the major, trace and isotopic geochemical data of the whole rock. The name of the file is "minmaj", which represents the data of mineral major elements.

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Petrogenesis of the Late Triassic diorites in the Hoh Xil area, northern Tibet: Insights into the origin of the high-Mg# andesitic signature of continental crust
literatureList.referenceEn: Wang, J., Gou, G.-N., Wang, Q., Zhang, C., Dan, W., Wyman, D. A., & Zhang, X.-Z. (2018). Petrogenesis of the Late Triassic diorites in the Hoh Xil area, northern Tibet: Insights into the origin of the high-Mg# andesitic signature of continental crust. Lithos, 300-301, 348-360. doi:10.1016/j.lithos.2017.12.007

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of geochemical datasets related to diorite rocks in the藏北可可西里地区五道梁 region?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock major and trace elements, mineral major elements, whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopes, zircon U–Pb ages, Hf isotopic data

Quantification.Question: How many different isotope analyses are conducted in a dataset related to the geochemistry of diorite from the Wudaoliang area in the northern Tibet Hoh Xil block?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of '锆石U–Pb年代学数据' in the context of geochemical data collection?
Definition.Answer: 锆石U–Pb年代学数据 refers to the zircon U-Pb geochronological data, which are obtained by analyzing zircon minerals using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to determine the age of rock formations.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the magmatic activity and deep dynamic mechanisms in the Tibetan region from analyzing the geochemical data and isotopic compositions of diorites?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical data and isotopic compositions of diorites offer insights into the timing, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatic activity in the Tibetan region. By examining zircon U–Pb ages and Hf isotopes, along with whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopes and major-trace geochemistry, researchers can constrain the age, genesis, and tectonic processes underlying the magmatic activities. This helps in understanding the characteristics and origin of high-magnesium andesitic features in the continental crust.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on the understanding of regional magmatic processes when using a dataset that includes whole-rock major and trace element geochemistry, mineral major element data, whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopes, zircon U–Pb ages, and Hf isotopes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a dataset that includes whole-rock major and trace element geochemistry, mineral major element data, whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopes, zircon U–Pb ages, and Hf isotopes can lead to a more comprehensive understanding of the timing, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of regional magmatic processes. It also enhances insights into the origin of high-magnesium andesite characteristics in continental crust.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective behind collecting geochemical and isotopic data from diorite samples in the Tibet Kekexili block to understand magmatic processes and crustal dynamics?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to define the age, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatism in the region and to provide insights into the origin of high-magnesium andesitic characteristics of continental crust.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental techniques and procedural steps used to obtain geochemical data and isotopic ages from diorite samples in the藏北可可西里地区五道梁闪长岩 region, and how do these methods contribute to understanding magmatic activity and crustal characteristics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumental techniques and procedural steps involve collecting diorite samples from the五道梁 region in northern Tibet, followed by the analysis of zircon U-Pb ages using laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). Zircon Hf isotopic data are acquired through laser ablation-multicollector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-MC-ICP-MS). Whole-rock major and trace geochemical data are obtained using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), while mineral major element data are analyzed using electron probe micro-analysis (EPMA). Whole-rock Sr–Nd isotopic compositions are determined through sample separation and purification followed by analysis with multi-receiver inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICP-MS). These methods allow researchers to define the timing, origin, and deep dynamic mechanisms of magmatic processes in the region and provide insights into the origin of high-magnesium andesite characteristics in continental crust.
